'''Bobby Ray Murcer''' (born [[May 20]], [[1946]], in [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]]) was a professional baseball player for 17 seasons. Married his high-school sweetheart, Diana Kay Rhodes, in 1966. After coming up briefly in with the [[New York Yankees]] in 1965 and 1966, Murcer fulfilled his military obligation in 1967 and 1968 before being called up to the majors to stay in 1969.
'''Bobby Ray Murcer''' (born [[May 20]], [[1946]], in [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]]) was a professional baseball player for 17 seasons. Married his high-school sweetheart, Diana Kay Rhodes, in 1966. After coming up briefly in with the [[New York Yankees]] in 1965 and 1966, Murcer fulfilled his military obligation in 1967 and 1968 before being called up to the majors to stay in 1969.
â
==he had no Career recap ==
+
== Career recap ==
Murcer averaged 21 [[home run]]s, 89 [[run batted in|RBIs]], and a .277 [[batting average|average]] over a full season during his career. A left-handed hitter, Murcer ended with 252 home runs, 1,043 RBIs, and a .277 average. He hit .301 with runners on third base. Was only the third New York Yankee ([[Joe DiMaggio]] and Mickey Mantle were the others) to make $100,000 a season and at 26 years of age was the youngest [[American League]] player ever to make a six-figure salary.<small>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Bobby_Murcer_1946]</small>
Murcer averaged 21 [[home run]]s, 89 [[run batted in|RBIs]], and a .277 [[batting average|average]] over a full season during his career. A left-handed hitter, Murcer ended with 252 home runs, 1,043 RBIs, and a .277 average. He hit .301 with runners on third base. Was only the third New York Yankee ([[Joe DiMaggio]] and Mickey Mantle were the others) to make $100,000 a season and at 26 years of age was the youngest [[American League]] player ever to make a six-figure salary.<small>[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=Bobby_Murcer_1946]</small>
Murcer made the [[All-Star]] teams in 1971-74 in the [[American League]] and 1975 in the [[National League]]. He also won a [[Gold Glove Award]] in 1972.
Murcer made the [[All-Star]] teams in 1971-74 in the [[American League]] and 1975 in the [[National League]]. He also won a [[Gold Glove Award]] in 1972.
Line 52: Line 52:
Against Hall of Fame pitchers Murcer hit .291 with 17 homers and 65 RBIs in 447 at bats. When [[Tommy John]] and [[Bert Blyleven]] (both possible Hall of Famers) are added, Murcer's numbers total 553 at bats with 20 home runs, 76 RBIs and a .297 average, seemingly stellar numbers versus such an elite group of pitchers.
Against Hall of Fame pitchers Murcer hit .291 with 17 homers and 65 RBIs in 447 at bats. When [[Tommy John]] and [[Bert Blyleven]] (both possible Hall of Famers) are added, Murcer's numbers total 553 at bats with 20 home runs, 76 RBIs and a .297 average, seemingly stellar numbers versus such an elite group of pitchers.
â
For the decade of the 1970s Murcer drove in 840 runs, the 9th most in Major League baseball during that span. Murcer's 119 outfield assists led all MLB outfielders for that decade as well, ahead of [[Bobby Bonds]] (106), [[Rusty Staub]] (97), [[Amos Otis]] (93), Reggie Smith (86), [[Jose Cardenal]] (85), Del Unser (82), and [[Reggie Jackson]] (81). <small>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/pi/bsl_finder.cgi#n1=&as=result_batter&offset=0&sum=1&min_year_season=1970&max_year_season=1979&isActive=either&isHOF=either&bats=any&throws=any&exactness=anypos&games_prop=50&games_tot=&pos_left_field=1&pos_center_field=1&pos_right_field=1&pos_out_field=1&qualifiersSeason=nomin&minpasValS=502&mingamesValS=100&qualifiersCareer=nomin&minpasValC=3000&mingamesValC=1000&c1val=0&c2val=0&c3val=0&c4val=0&min_season=1&max_season=-1&min_age=0&max_age=99&lg_ID=lgAny&lgAL_team=tmAny&lgNL_team=tmAny&lgFL_team=tmAny&lgAA_team=tmAny&lgPL_team=tmAny&lgUA_team=tmAny&lgNA_team=tmAny&orderby=HR&layout=full&c1bsl=&c1gtlt=gt&c2bsl=&c2gtlt=gt&c3bsl=&c3gtlt=gt&c4bsl=&c4gtlt=gt&location=pob&locationMatch=is&pob=&pod=&pcanada=&pusa=]</small> His 198 homers tied for 17th in the major leagues for the 1970s and his .282 batting average was 20th among all players who had 5,000 or more plate appearances. During the 1970s he led his club in home runs six times (1970, 71, 72, 73, 76, 77). and why waist your time on this guy when you could get drunk and high, oh by the way he was a dope head and a porn star. and piss on you. THIS NEVER HAPPENED
+
For the decade of the 1970s Murcer drove in 840 runs, the 9th most in Major League baseball during that span. Murcer's 119 outfield assists led all MLB outfielders for that decade as well, ahead of [[Bobby Bonds]] (106), [[Rusty Staub]] (97), [[Amos Otis]] (93), Reggie Smith (86), [[Jose Cardenal]] (85), Del Unser (82), and [[Reggie Jackson]] (81). <small>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/pi/bsl_finder.cgi#n1=&as=result_batter&offset=0&sum=1&min_year_season=1970&max_year_season=1979&isActive=either&isHOF=either&bats=any&throws=any&exactness=anypos&games_prop=50&games_tot=&pos_left_field=1&pos_center_field=1&pos_right_field=1&pos_out_field=1&qualifiersSeason=nomin&minpasValS=502&mingamesValS=100&qualifiersCareer=nomin&minpasValC=3000&mingamesValC=1000&c1val=0&c2val=0&c3val=0&c4val=0&min_season=1&max_season=-1&min_age=0&max_age=99&lg_ID=lgAny&lgAL_team=tmAny&lgNL_team=tmAny&lgFL_team=tmAny&lgAA_team=tmAny&lgPL_team=tmAny&lgUA_team=tmAny&lgNA_team=tmAny&orderby=HR&layout=full&c1bsl=&c1gtlt=gt&c2bsl=&c2gtlt=gt&c3bsl=&c3gtlt=gt&c4bsl=&c4gtlt=gt&location=pob&locationMatch=is&pob=&pod=&pcanada=&pusa=]</small> His 198 homers tied for 17th in the major leagues for the 1970s and his .282 batting average was 20th among all players who had 5,000 or more plate appearances. During the 1970s he led his club in home runs six times (1970, 71, 72, 73, 76, 77).
â
==High School sex life career==
+
==High School career==
â
Played football, baseball, and basketball teams as a sophomore at Southeast High School in Oklahoma City. In his junior year, he made the all-district football team. He also helped Southeast High to the conference championship in baseball. As a senior Murcer showed his athletic abilities by making All-State in both football (the states leading scorer) and baseball and was All-City (led the city in scoring) in basketball. He was offered a football scholarship by the University of Oklahoma.<small>[http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=10146&bid=831]</small> HE ALWAYS FUCKED HIS BIOLOGY TEACHERS
+
Played football, baseball, and basketball teams as a sophomore at Southeast High School in Oklahoma City. In his junior year, he made the all-district football team. He also helped Southeast High to the conference championship in baseball. As a senior Murcer showed his athletic abilities by making All-State in both football (the states leading scorer) and baseball and was All-City (led the city in scoring) in basketball. He was offered a football scholarship by the University of Oklahoma.<small>[http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=10146&bid=831]</small>
